title: Bipartisan bill would raise payments for wrongfully convicted inmates
text:
Bipartisan bill would raise payments for wrongfully convicted inmates By Jason Stein (2) Comments 
Madison — Wisconsin would no longer offer wrongfully convicted prisoners the lowest compensation in the nation, under a bipartisan bill announced Thursday. 
Under the bill, innocent inmates could seek up to $50,000 a year in compensation up to a $1 million cap for prisoners of two decades or more; purchase health insurance; and get the kinds of transitional services that are currently given only to guilty inmates on their release, not to those prisoners of the state who can now prove they are innocent. The potential financial compensation would be similar to what the federal government now offers. 
"This is about doing what's right. This is about integrity," said Sen. Van Wanggaard (R-Racine), a former police officer. "When we do get it wrong, we have to make it right." 
Currently, Wisconsin law provides exonerated inmates no more than $5,000 for each lost year of their life, up to a total of $25,000. Of the states with laws providing for payments to the wrongfully convicted, Wisconsin has the lowest amount per year, said Keith Findley, co-director of the Wisconsin Innocence Project, which has helped overturn the convictions of wrongfully accused prisoners. 
Since 1990, roughly 40 inmates have been exonerated and released, supporters of the bill said at a statehouse news conference. Rep. Gary Hebl (D-Sun Prairie) and Rep. Dale Kooyenga (R-Brookfield) said that the measure's sponsors are considering making the bill retroactive in light of that fact. 
But Findley said that not all of the 40 prisoners would qualify for additional compensation. Some have died or can't be located or wouldn't successfully complete the application process, he said. © 2015 , Journal Sentinel Inc. All rights reserved. About Jason Stein 
Jason Stein covers the state Capitol and is the author with his colleague Patrick Marley of "More than They Bargained For: Scott Walker, Unions and the Fight for Wisconsin." His work has been recognized by journalism groups such as the American Society of News Editors, the Society of American Business Editors and Writers, and the Association of Capitol Reporters and Editors.
